physical_examinations.vital_signs: Heart rate increased during anger attacks; face flushed.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Mr. A displayed signs of tachycardia and flushing during episodes of anger, indicating significant autonomic arousal.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Within 3 weeks of treatment, Mr. A reported no loss of control and cessation of outbursts.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Ms. B described chest tightness, feeling hot, and palpitations during anger attacks.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: After starting treatment with clomipramine, she reported feeling better and returned to work within one week. Recurrences occurred after medication discontinuation, followed by improvement upon restarting treatment.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: Increased heart rate, sweating, and flushing during anger episodes.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Ms. C reported hyperventilation, sweating, and feelings of rage during episodes.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: After treatment with clonazepam and desipramine, hostility score improved, and she reported no anger attacks for about a month.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: Flushed face, increased heart rate, and feeling hot during outbursts.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Mr. D experienced a marked improvement in behavior after treatment with clomipramine.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Following prescription renewal and treatment, he had no anger attacks for the next four months.
